Title:
Evolutionary constraints of two independently duplicated
genes encoding UDP- glucose: glycoprotein glucosyltransferases in
Caenorhabditis and vertebrates
Keywords:
UDP- glucose: glycoprotein glucosyltransferase -
Caenorhabditis elegans  Vertebrates  Purifying selection  Positive
selection  Neofunctionalization - Specialization
Abstract:
Background UDP- glucose: glycoprotein glucosyltransferase
(UGGT) is a protein that operates as the gatekeeper for the endoplasmic
reticulum (ER) quality control mechanism of glycoprotein folding. It is
known that Mus, Homo sapiens and Caenorhabditis genomes harbor two
copies of uggt genes that exhibit differences in their properties. The
emergence of a novel biological function is often associated with gene
duplication where one of the copies retains the original function
whereas the other acquires a new one. Different evolutionary forces act
on each paralogue: purifying selection ensures the retention of the
original function while relaxed purifying selection and/or positive
selection enable the eventual emergence of a new function. In order to
determine if this is the case for uggt genes, we gained insight into
their origin and molecular evolution in two eukaryotic lineages
-Caenorhabditis and vertebrates- that harbor two copies of this gene.
Results Bayesian phylogenetic inference based on 189 UGGT and UGGT-like
protein sequences of an ample spectrum of eukaryotic species showed that
uggt genes went through independent duplications in Caenorhabditis and
vertebrates lineages. Whereas in Caenorhabditis overall substitution
rates in UGGT2 were markedly higher than in UGGT1, in vertebrates this
difference was slight. We employed codon- and lineage-based Bayesian and
maximum likelihood approaches depicting that the protein’s recognition
and catalytic domains evolved under different evolutionary scenarios in
uggt-2 genes in both lineages. While the catalytic domain was subjected
to a strongly negative selective pressure, the recognition domain
underwent an episodic positive diversifying selection process. Selective
relaxation in the recognition domain was more pronounced in
Caenorhabditis than in vertebrates. Conclusions The independent
duplications which originated the second uggt copy in Caenorhabditis and
vertebrates gave rise to different evolutionary histories of the
resulting copies. The present results support the conservation of the
UDP-glucose: glycoprotein glucosyltransferase activity in the catalytic
domain and a divergent function of the recognition domain for the uggt-2
gene in vertebrates, which would have gone through a specialization
process. In Caenorhabditis, the uggt-2 gene evolved under different
constraints compared to uggt-1 which, by means of a neofunctionalization
process, resulted in a non-redundant paralogue. The non-canonical
function of uggt-2 in the worm lineage highlights the need to take
precautions before generalizing gene functions in model organisms.
